tn.ref: Open your doors, Lebanon, that fire may devour your cedars
tn.text: The prophet is speaking to the land of Lebanon as if it were a person. AT: "People of Lebanon, get ready for fire to burn up your cedar trees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])

tn.ref: Lament, cypress trees, for the cedar trees have fallen
tn.text: AT: "If the trees were people, they would cry out in sorrow. The cypress trees stand alone because the cedars have burned and fallen." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Lament, you oaks of Bashan, for the strong forest has gone down.
tn.text: AT: "If the oak trees in Bashan were people, they would wail, for their thick forests have been cut down." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
AT: "The shepherds cry out loudly"

tn.ref: for their glory has been destroyed
tn.text: "Their glory" probably represents the rich pastures that the shepherds led their sheep to. AT: "for their rich pastures have been ruined."

tn.ref: for the pride of the Jordan River
tn.text: AT: "because the trees and shrubbery where they lived by the Jordan River have been destroyed."
Here Yahweh starts to give instructions to Zechariah in the form of a parable about shepherds and sheep.
"the people of the land"
This phrase is often translated as "Yahweh says" in the UDB. You can translate this concept whichever way is best in your language. This phrase is used many times in Zechariah.

tn.ref: turn over every person into the hand of his neighbor
tn.text: AT: "allow each person to be controlled by another person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: into the hand of his king
tn.text: AT: "into the unjust control of his king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "they will have no mercy on the land's people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: none of them will I deliver them from their hand
tn.text: AT: "but I will not rescue the people of Judah from their power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The parable about shepherds and sheep continues.
"the flock of sheep that was intended for slaughter."
Staffs are wooden sticks used for various purposes, including directing sheep. Staffs may have different types of hooks on the ends.
Various versions also translate the Hebrew word in this text as "grace" and "beauty."
This is the idea of brotherhood between the two parts of Israel, the northern kingdom and the southern kingdom.

tn.ref: I ran out of patience with them
tn.text: AT: "I could no longer tolerate the sheep owners who had hired me."
The parable about shepherds and sheep continues.

tn.ref: broke it to break the covenant that I had made with all of my tribes
tn.text: The prophet is speaking and acting for Yahweh here.
AT: "had spoken a message to them"
330 grams of silver. A shekel weighed eleven grams. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
The parable about shepherds and sheep continues.
the storehouses in the temple of Yahweh

This means to say that this price was very small for a shepherd doing Yahweh's work. See UDB, which removes the irony: "a ridiculously small amount of money." (See: [[[[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
330 grams of silver. A shekel weighed eleven grams. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
The parable about shepherds and sheep continues.
the healthy, well-grown sheep
probably as an act of cruelty
The parable about shepherds and sheep continues.
AT: "What sorrow waits for this worthless shepherd"

tn.ref: come against his arm and his right eye
tn.text: AT: "wound right arm and pierce his right eye!"
"Sword" here represents enemies who will attack the shepherd. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
his power to fight (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
his ability to see while fighting.
